author: definitelynotcharles7176
content:
Is there a place I can ask why ETH doesn't increase transaction limits greatly for ETH 1X? 

It seems like on its face that the hardware costs for the relevant enlargements are low next to current resources put into mining. It doesn't seem overly difficult to imagine ways to incentivize resources already demonstrably available.

Also, what is the counterpoint to the (maybe derogatory) critique that the inability to implement schemes to enable higher transactions per second seems dubious and signals some sort of lack of effectiveness?

author: pietjepuk
content:
> Is there a place I can ask why ETH doesn't increase transaction limits greatly for ETH 1X? 
It does though? Work is actively under way to better facilitate roll-ups. See e.g.  https://ethereum-magicians.org/t/a-rollup-centric-ethereum-roadmap/4698 for discussion.

> It seems like on its face that the hardware costs for the relevant enlargements are low next to current resources put into mining. It doesn't seem overly difficult to imagine ways to incentivize resources already demonstrably available.
> 
> Also, what is the counterpoint to the (maybe derogatory) critique that the inability to implement schemes to enable higher transactions per second seems dubious and signals some sort of lack of effectiveness?
As far as "just raising" the gas limit is concerned, all nodes (not just miners) pay the price on the resulting increasing state size. We want just about everyone to be able to validate transactions/blocks themselves. Note that there is also work underway on this front (some hinting at "super nodes" that are indeed much more powerful, but don't require deferring validation/trust). Still mostly in the phase of how to best address it in the short-term, mid-term, and long-term: https://ethresear.ch/t/alternative-bounded-state-friendly-address-scheme/8602  , https://dankradfeist.de/ethereum/2021/02/14/why-stateless.html .
